@timestamp.description:
Date/time when the event originated.
This is the date/time extracted from the event, typically representing when the event was generated by the source.
If the event source has no original timestamp, this value is typically populated by the first time the event was received by the pipeline.
Required field for all events.
@timestamp.name: @timestamp

agent.ephemeral_id.description:
Ephemeral identifier of this agent (if one exists).
This id normally changes across restarts, but `agent.id` does not.
agent.ephemeral_id.name: ephemeral_id

agent.id.description:
Unique identifier of this agent (if one exists).
Example: For Beats this would be beat.id.
agent.id.name: id

agent.name.description:
Custom name of the agent.
This is a name that can be given to an agent. This can be helpful if for example two Filebeat instances are running on the same host but a human readable separation is needed on which Filebeat instance data is coming from.
If no name is given, the name is often left empty.
agent.name.name: name

agent.type.description:
Type of the agent.
The agent type stays always the same and should be given by the agent used. In case of Filebeat the agent would always be Filebeat also if two Filebeat instances are run on the same machine.
agent.type.name: type

client.address.description:
Some event client addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.
client.address.name: address

client.bytes.description: Bytes sent from the client to the server.
client.bytes.name: bytes
client.bytes.short: Bytes sent from the client to the server.

client.geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
client.geo.name.name: name

client.ip.description:
IP address of the client.
Can be one or multiple IPv4 or IPv6 addresses.
client.ip.name: ip

client.packets.description: Packets sent from the client to the server.
client.packets.name: packets
client.packets.short: Packets sent from the client to the server.

client.user.group.id.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.
client.user.group.id.name: id
client.user.group.id.short: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

client.user.hash.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.
client.user.hash.name: hash
client.user.hash.short: Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.

client.user.id.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.
client.user.id.name: id
client.user.id.short: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

client.user.name.description: Short name or login of the user.
client.user.name.name: name
client.user.name.short: Short name or login of the user.

cloud.account.id.description:
The cloud account or organization id used to identify different entities in a multi-tenant environment.
Examples: AWS account id, Google Cloud ORG Id, or other unique identifier.
cloud.account.id.name: account.id
cloud.account.id.short: The cloud account or organization id.

cloud.availability_zone.description: Availability zone in which this host is running.
cloud.availability_zone.name: availability_zone
cloud.availability_zone.short: Availability zone in which this host is running.

cloud.instance.id.description: Instance ID of the host machine.
cloud.instance.id.name: instance.id
cloud.instance.id.short: Instance ID of the host machine.

cloud.instance.name.description: Instance name of the host machine.
cloud.instance.name.name: instance.name
cloud.instance.name.short: Instance name of the host machine.

cloud.machine.type.description: Machine type of the host machine.
cloud.machine.type.name: machine.type
cloud.machine.type.short: Machine type of the host machine.

cloud.provider.description: Name of the cloud provider. Example values are aws, azure, gcp, or digitalocean.
cloud.provider.name: provider

cloud.region.description: Region in which this host is running.
cloud.region.name: region
cloud.region.short: Region in which this host is running.

container.image.name.description: Name of the image the container was built on.
container.image.name.name: image.name
container.image.name.short: Name of the image the container was built on.

destination.address.description:
Some event destination addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.
destination.address.name: address

destination.bytes.description: Bytes sent from the destination to the source.
destination.bytes.name: bytes
destination.bytes.short: Bytes sent from the destination to the source.

destination.geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
destination.geo.name.name: name

destination.ip.description:
IP address of the destination.
Can be one or multiple IPv4 or IPv6 addresses.
destination.ip.name: ip

destination.packets.description: Packets sent from the destination to the source.
destination.packets.name: packets
destination.packets.short: Packets sent from the destination to the source.

destination.user.group.id.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.
destination.user.group.id.name: id
destination.user.group.id.short: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

destination.user.hash.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.
destination.user.hash.name: hash
destination.user.hash.short: Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.

destination.user.id.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.
destination.user.id.name: id
destination.user.id.short: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

destination.user.name.description: Short name or login of the user.
destination.user.name.name: name
destination.user.name.short: Short name or login of the user.

ecs.version.description:
ECS version this event conforms to. `ecs.version` is a required field and must exist in all events.
When querying across multiple indices -- which may conform to slightly different ECS versions -- this field lets integrations adjust to the schema version of the events.
ecs.version.name: version
ecs.version.short: ECS version this event conforms to.

event.action.description:
The action captured by the event.
This describes the information in the event. It is more specific than `event.category`. Examples are `group-add`, `process-started`, `file-created`. The value is normally defined by the implementer.
event.action.name: action
event.action.short: The action captured by the event.

event.category.description:
Event category.
This contains high-level information about the contents of the event. It is more generic than `event.action`, in the sense that typically a category contains multiple actions. Warning: In future versions of ECS, we plan to provide a list of acceptable values for this field, please use with caution.
event.category.name: category

event.created.description:
event.created contains the date/time when the event was first read by an agent, or by your pipeline.
This field is distinct from @timestamp in that @timestamp typically contain the time extracted from the original event.
In most situations, these two timestamps will be slightly different. The difference can be used to calculate the delay between your source generating an event, and the time when your agent first processed it. This can be used to monitor your agent's or pipeline's ability to keep up with your event source.
In case the two timestamps are identical, @timestamp should be used.
event.created.name: created
event.created.short: Time when the event was first read by an agent or by your pipeline.

event.dataset.description:
Name of the dataset.
The concept of a `dataset` (fileset / metricset) is used in Beats as a subset of modules. It contains the information which is currently stored in metricset.name and metricset.module or fileset.name.
event.dataset.name: dataset

event.duration.description:
Duration of the event in nanoseconds.
If event.start and event.end are known this value should be the difference between the end and start time.
event.duration.name: duration
event.duration.short: Duration of the event in nanoseconds.

event.end.description: event.end contains the date when the event ended or when the activity was last observed.
event.end.name: end
event.end.short: event.end contains the date when the event ended or when the activity was last observed.

event.hash.description: Hash (perhaps logstash fingerprint) of raw field to be able to demonstrate log integrity.
event.hash.name: hash
event.hash.short: Hash (perhaps logstash fingerprint) of raw field to be able to demonstrate log integrity.

event.id.description: Unique ID to describe the event.
event.id.name: id
event.id.short: Unique ID to describe the event.

event.kind.description:
The kind of the event.
This gives information about what type of information the event contains, without being specific to the contents of the event.  Examples are `event`, `state`, `alarm`. Warning: In future versions of ECS, we plan to provide a list of acceptable values for this field, please use with caution.
event.kind.name: kind

event.module.description:
Name of the module this data is coming from.
This information is coming from the modules used in Beats or Logstash.
event.module.name: module
event.module.short: Name of the module this data is coming from.

event.original.description:
Raw text message of entire event. Used to demonstrate log integrity.
This field is not indexed and doc_values are disabled. It cannot be searched, but it can be retrieved from `_source`.
event.original.example: Sep 19 08:26:10 host CEF:0|Security| threatmanager|1.0|100| worm successfully stopped|10|src=10.0.0.1 dst=2.1.2.2spt=1232
event.original.name: original
event.original.short: Raw text message of entire event.

event.outcome.description:
The outcome of the event.
If the event describes an action, this fields contains the outcome of that action. Examples outcomes are `success` and `failure`. Warning: In future versions of ECS, we plan to provide a list of acceptable values for this field, please use with caution.
event.outcome.name: outcome

event.risk_score.description: Risk score or priority of the event (e.g. security solutions). Use your system's original value here.
event.risk_score.name: risk_score
event.risk_score.short: Risk score or priority of the event (e.g. security solutions). Use your system's original value here.

event.risk_score_norm.description:
Normalized risk score or priority of the event, on a scale of 0 to 100.
This is mainly useful if you use more than one system that assigns risk scores, and you want to see a normalized value across all systems.
event.risk_score_norm.name: risk_score_norm
event.risk_score_norm.short: Normalized risk score or priority of the event (0-100).

event.severity.description: Severity describes the original severity of the event. What the different severity values mean can very different between use cases. It's up to the implementer to make sure severities are consistent across events.
event.severity.name: severity

event.start.description: event.start contains the date when the event started or when the activity was first observed.
event.start.name: start
event.start.short: event.start contains the date when the event started or when the activity was first observed.

event.timezone.description:
This field should be populated when the event's timestamp does not include timezone information already (e.g. default Syslog timestamps). It's optional otherwise.
Acceptable timezone formats are: a canonical ID (e.g. "Europe/Amsterdam"), abbreviated (e.g. "EST") or an HH:mm differential (e.g. "-05:00").
event.timezone.name: timezone

event.type.description:
Reserved for future usage.
Please avoid using this field for user data.
event.type.name: type

file.device.description: Device that is the source of the file.
file.device.name: device
file.device.short: Device that is the source of the file.

file.extension.description:
File extension.
This should allow easy filtering by file extensions.
file.extension.name: extension

file.gid.description: Primary group ID (GID) of the file.
file.gid.name: gid
file.gid.short: Primary group ID (GID) of the file.

file.group.description: Primary group name of the file.
file.group.name: group
file.group.short: Primary group name of the file.

file.inode.description: Inode representing the file in the filesystem.
file.inode.name: inode
file.inode.short: Inode representing the file in the filesystem.

file.mode.description: Mode of the file in octal representation.
file.mode.name: mode
file.mode.short: Mode of the file in octal representation.

file.mtime.description: Last time file content was modified.
file.mtime.name: mtime
file.mtime.short: Last time file content was modified.

file.size.description: File size in bytes (field is only added when `type` is `file`).
file.size.name: size
file.size.short: File size in bytes (field is only added when `type` is `file`).

file.uid.description: The user ID (UID) or security identifier (SID) of the file owner.
file.uid.name: uid
file.uid.short: The user ID (UID) or security identifier (SID) of the file owner.

geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
geo.name.name: name

group.id.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.
group.id.name: id
group.id.short: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

host.geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
host.geo.name.name: name

host.hostname.description:
Hostname of the host.
It normally contains what the `hostname` command returns on the host machine.
host.hostname.name: hostname

host.id.description:
Unique host id.
As hostname is not always unique, use values that are meaningful in your environment.
Example: The current usage of `beat.name`.
host.id.name: id

host.name.description:
Name of the host.
It can contain what `hostname` returns on Unix systems, the fully qualified domain name, or a name specified by the user. The sender decides which value to use.
host.name.name: name

host.os.family.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).
host.os.family.name: family
host.os.family.short: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

host.os.full.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.
host.os.full.name: full
host.os.full.short: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

host.os.kernel.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.
host.os.kernel.name: kernel
host.os.kernel.short: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

host.os.name.description: Operating system name, without the version.
host.os.name.name: name
host.os.name.short: Operating system name, without the version.

host.os.platform.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).
host.os.platform.name: platform
host.os.platform.short: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

host.os.version.description: Operating system version as a raw string.
host.os.version.name: version
host.os.version.short: Operating system version as a raw string.

host.type.description:
Type of host.
For Cloud providers this can be the machine type like `t2.medium`. If vm, this could be the container, for example, or other information meaningful in your environment.
host.type.name: type

host.user.group.id.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.
host.user.group.id.name: id
host.user.group.id.short: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

host.user.hash.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.
host.user.hash.name: hash
host.user.hash.short: Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.

host.user.id.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.
host.user.id.name: id
host.user.id.short: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

host.user.name.description: Short name or login of the user.
host.user.name.name: name
host.user.name.short: Short name or login of the user.

http.request.body.bytes.description: Size in bytes of the request body.
http.request.body.bytes.name: request.body.bytes
http.request.body.bytes.short: Size in bytes of the request body.

http.request.bytes.description: Total size in bytes of the request (body and headers).
http.request.bytes.name: request.bytes
http.request.bytes.short: Total size in bytes of the request (body and headers).

http.request.method.description:
HTTP request method.
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying. See the documentation section "Implementing ECS".
http.request.method.name: request.method

http.response.body.bytes.description: Size in bytes of the response body.
http.response.body.bytes.name: response.body.bytes
http.response.body.bytes.short: Size in bytes of the response body.

http.response.bytes.description: Total size in bytes of the response (body and headers).
http.response.bytes.name: response.bytes
http.response.bytes.short: Total size in bytes of the response (body and headers).

labels.description:
Custom key/value pairs.
Can be used to add meta information to events. Should not contain nested objects. All values are stored as keyword.
Example: `docker` and `k8s` labels.
labels.name: labels

log.level.description:
Original log level of the log event.
Some examples are `warn`, `error`, `i`.
log.level.name: level
log.level.short: Log level of the log event.

log.original.description:
This is the original log message and contains the full log message before splitting it up in multiple parts.
In contrast to the `message` field which can contain an extracted part of the log message, this field contains the original, full log message. It can have already some modifications applied like encoding or new lines removed to clean up the log message.
This field is not indexed and doc_values are disabled so it can't be queried but the value can be retrieved from `_source`.
log.original.name: original
log.original.short: Original log message with light interpretation only (encoding, newlines).

message.description:
For log events the message field contains the log message, optimized for viewing in a log viewer.
For structured logs without an original message field, other fields can be concatenated to form a human-readable summary of the event.
If multiple messages exist, they can be combined into one message.
message.name: message
message.short: Log message optimized for viewing in a log viewer.

network.application.description:
A name given to an application level protocol. This can be arbitrarily assigned for things like microservices, but also apply to things like skype, icq, facebook, twitter. This would be used in situations where the vendor or service can be decoded such as from the source/dest IP owners, ports, or wire format.
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying. See the documentation section "Implementing ECS".
network.application.name: application

network.bytes.description:
Total bytes transferred in both directions.
If `source.bytes` and `destination.bytes` are known, `network.bytes` is their sum.
network.bytes.name: bytes
network.bytes.short: Total bytes transferred in both directions.

network.community_id.description:
A hash of source and destination IPs and ports, as well as the protocol used in a communication. This is a tool-agnostic standard to identify flows.
Learn more at https://github.com/corelight/community-id-spec.
network.community_id.name: community_id
network.community_id.short: A hash of source and destination IPs and ports.

network.direction.description:
Direction of the network traffic.
Recommended values are:
  * inbound
  * outbound
  * internal
  * external
  * unknown

When mapping events from a host-based monitoring context, populate this field from the host's point of view.
When mapping events from a network or perimeter-based monitoring context, populate this field from the point of view of your network perimeter.
network.direction.name: direction

network.forwarded_ip.description: Host IP address when the source IP address is the proxy.
network.forwarded_ip.name: forwarded_ip
network.forwarded_ip.short: Host IP address when the source IP address is the proxy.

network.iana_number.description: IANA Protocol Number (https://www.iana.org/assignments/protocol-numbers/protocol-numbers.xhtml). Standardized list of protocols. This aligns well with NetFlow and sFlow related logs which use the IANA Protocol Number.
network.iana_number.name: iana_number

network.name.description: Name given by operators to sections of their network.
network.name.name: name
network.name.short: Name given by operators to sections of their network.

network.packets.description:
Total packets transferred in both directions.
If `source.packets` and `destination.packets` are known, `network.packets` is their sum.
network.packets.name: packets
network.packets.short: Total packets transferred in both directions.

network.protocol.description:
L7 Network protocol name. ex. http, lumberjack, transport protocol.
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying. See the documentation section "Implementing ECS".
network.protocol.name: protocol

network.transport.description:
Same as network.iana_number, but instead using the Keyword name of the transport layer (udp, tcp, ipv6-icmp, etc.)
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying. See the documentation section "Implementing ECS".
network.transport.name: transport
network.transport.short: Protocol Name corresponding to the field `iana_number`.

network.type.description:
In the OSI Model this would be the Network Layer. ipv4, ipv6, ipsec, pim, etc
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying. See the documentation section "Implementing ECS".
network.type.name: type
network.type.short: In the OSI Model this would be the Network Layer. ipv4, ipv6, ipsec, pim, etc

observer.geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
observer.geo.name.name: name

observer.os.family.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).
observer.os.family.name: family
observer.os.family.short: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

observer.os.full.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.
observer.os.full.name: full
observer.os.full.short: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

observer.os.kernel.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.
observer.os.kernel.name: kernel
observer.os.kernel.short: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

observer.os.name.description: Operating system name, without the version.
observer.os.name.name: name
observer.os.name.short: Operating system name, without the version.

observer.os.platform.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).
observer.os.platform.name: platform
observer.os.platform.short: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

observer.os.version.description: Operating system version as a raw string.
observer.os.version.name: version
observer.os.version.short: Operating system version as a raw string.

observer.type.description:
The type of the observer the data is coming from.
There is no predefined list of observer types. Some examples are `forwarder`, `firewall`, `ids`, `ips`, `proxy`, `poller`, `sensor`, `APM server`.
observer.type.name: type
observer.type.short: The type of the observer the data is coming from.

os.family.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).
os.family.name: family
os.family.short: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

os.full.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.
os.full.name: full
os.full.short: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

os.kernel.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.
os.kernel.name: kernel
os.kernel.short: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

os.name.description: Operating system name, without the version.
os.name.name: name
os.name.short: Operating system name, without the version.

os.platform.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).
os.platform.name: platform
os.platform.short: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

os.version.description: Operating system version as a raw string.
os.version.name: version
os.version.short: Operating system version as a raw string.

process.args.description:
Array of process arguments.
May be filtered to protect sensitive information.
process.args.name: args

process.executable.description: Absolute path to the process executable.
process.executable.name: executable
process.executable.short: Absolute path to the process executable.

process.name.description:
Process name.
Sometimes called program name or similar.
process.name.name: name

process.title.description:
Process title.
The proctitle, some times the same as process name. Can also be different: for example a browser setting its title to the web page currently opened.
process.title.name: title

process.working_directory.description: The working directory of the process.
process.working_directory.name: working_directory
process.working_directory.short: The working directory of the process.

related.ip.description: All of the IPs seen on your event.
related.ip.name: ip
related.ip.short: All of the IPs seen on your event.

server.address.description:
Some event server addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.
server.address.name: address

server.bytes.description: Bytes sent from the server to the client.
server.bytes.name: bytes
server.bytes.short: Bytes sent from the server to the client.

server.geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
server.geo.name.name: name

server.ip.description:
IP address of the server.
Can be one or multiple IPv4 or IPv6 addresses.
server.ip.name: ip

server.packets.description: Packets sent from the server to the client.
server.packets.name: packets
server.packets.short: Packets sent from the server to the client.

server.user.group.id.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.
server.user.group.id.name: id
server.user.group.id.short: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

server.user.hash.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.
server.user.hash.name: hash
server.user.hash.short: Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.

server.user.id.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.
server.user.id.name: id
server.user.id.short: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

server.user.name.description: Short name or login of the user.
server.user.name.name: name
server.user.name.short: Short name or login of the user.

service.ephemeral_id.description:
Ephemeral identifier of this service (if one exists).
This id normally changes across restarts, but `service.id` does not.
service.ephemeral_id.name: ephemeral_id

service.id.description:
Unique identifier of the running service.
This id should uniquely identify this service. This makes it possible to correlate logs and metrics for one specific service.
Example: If you are experiencing issues with one redis instance, you can filter on that id to see metrics and logs for that single instance.
service.id.name: id
service.id.short: Unique identifier of the running service.

service.name.description:
Name of the service data is collected from.
The name of the service is normally user given. This allows if two instances of the same service are running on the same machine they can be differentiated by the `service.name`.
Also it allows for distributed services that run on multiple hosts to correlate the related instances based on the name.
In the case of Elasticsearch the service.name could contain the cluster name. For Beats the service.name is by default a copy of the `service.type` field if no name is specified.
service.name.name: name

service.type.description:
The type of the service data is collected from.
The type can be used to group and correlate logs and metrics from one service type.
Example: If logs or metrics are collected from Elasticsearch, `service.type` would be `elasticsearch`.
service.type.name: type

service.version.description:
Version of the service the data was collected from.
This allows to look at a data set only for a specific version of a service.
service.version.name: version

source.address.description:
Some event source addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.
source.address.name: address

source.bytes.description: Bytes sent from the source to the destination.
source.bytes.name: bytes
source.bytes.short: Bytes sent from the source to the destination.

source.geo.name.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.
source.geo.name.name: name

source.ip.description:
IP address of the source.
Can be one or multiple IPv4 or IPv6 addresses.
source.ip.name: ip

source.packets.description: Packets sent from the source to the destination.
source.packets.name: packets
source.packets.short: Packets sent from the source to the destination.

source.user.group.id.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.
source.user.group.id.name: id
source.user.group.id.short: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

source.user.hash.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.
source.user.hash.name: hash
source.user.hash.short: Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.

source.user.id.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.
source.user.id.name: id
source.user.id.short: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

source.user.name.description: Short name or login of the user.
source.user.name.name: name
source.user.name.short: Short name or login of the user.

tags.description: List of keywords used to tag each event.
tags.name: tags
tags.short: List of keywords used to tag each event.

url.domain.description:
Domain of the url, such as "www.elastic.co".
In some cases a URL may refer to an IP and/or port directly, without a domain name. In this case, the IP address would go to the `domain` field.
url.domain.name: domain

url.fragment.description:
Portion of the url after the `#`, such as "top".
The `#` is not part of the fragment.
url.fragment.name: fragment
url.fragment.short: Portion of the url after the `#`.

url.full.description: If full URLs are important to your use case, they should be stored in `url.full`, whether this field is reconstructed or present in the event source.
url.full.name: full

url.original.description:
Unmodified original url as seen in the event source.
Note that in network monitoring, the observed URL may be a full URL, whereas in access logs, the URL is often just represented as a path.
This field is meant to represent the URL as it was observed, complete or not.
url.original.name: original
url.original.short: Unmodified original url as seen in the event source.

url.path.description: Path of the request, such as "/search".
url.path.name: path
url.path.short: Path of the request, such as "/search".

url.port.description: Port of the request, such as 443.
url.port.name: port
url.port.short: Port of the request, such as 443.

url.query.description:
The query field describes the query string of the request, such as "q=elasticsearch".
The `?` is excluded from the query string. If a URL contains no `?`, there is no query field. If there is a `?` but no query, the query field exists with an empty string. The `exists` query can be used to differentiate between the two cases.
url.query.name: query

url.scheme.description:
Scheme of the request, such as "https".
Note: The `:` is not part of the scheme.
url.scheme.name: scheme

user.group.id.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.
user.group.id.name: id
user.group.id.short: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

user.hash.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.
user.hash.name: hash
user.hash.short: Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.

user.id.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.
user.id.name: id
user.id.short: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

user.name.description: Short name or login of the user.
user.name.name: name
user.name.short: Short name or login of the user.

user_agent.original.example: Mozilla/5.0 (iPhone; CPU iPhone OS 12_1 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/605.1.15 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/12.0 Mobile/15E148 Safari/604.1
user_agent.original.name: original

user_agent.os.family.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).
user_agent.os.family.name: family
user_agent.os.family.short: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

user_agent.os.full.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.
user_agent.os.full.name: full
user_agent.os.full.short: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

user_agent.os.kernel.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.
user_agent.os.kernel.name: kernel
user_agent.os.kernel.short: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

user_agent.os.name.description: Operating system name, without the version.
user_agent.os.name.name: name
user_agent.os.name.short: Operating system name, without the version.

user_agent.os.platform.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).
user_agent.os.platform.name: platform
user_agent.os.platform.short: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

user_agent.os.version.description: Operating system version as a raw string.
user_agent.os.version.name: version
user_agent.os.version.short: Operating system version as a raw string.
